back: The sum of $n$ vectors \(\mathbf{a}\) and   \(\mathbf{b}\) is a vector \(\mathbf{a+b}\) such that any component $i$ of the   vector sum is the sum of the \(i\)th components of \(\mathbf{a}\) and   \(\mathbf{b}\); i.e. \(\mathbf{(a+b)}_i = a_i + b_i,~~i=0, 1,\ldots, n-1\).
Given a vector \(\mathbf{u}\) and a scalar \(\alpha\), define \(\alpha \mathbf{u}\) such that each component \(i\) of \(\alpha \mathbf{u}\) is given by \((\alpha \mathbf{u})_i = \alpha u_i\).

In NumPy, broadcasting occurs in operations involving two arrays of different shapes. The smaller array is broadcast across the larger array by repeating values in the smaller array in such a way that the shapes of the two arrays will match.

front:
component-wise multiplication (vectors)
or
Hadamard product (vectors)
or
Schur product (vectors)
back: Given \(n\)-vectors \(\mathbf{u}\) and \(\mathbf{v}\), the Hadamard product or Schur product is denoted \(\mathbf{u} \odot \mathbf{v}\) and is the \(n\)-vector given by component-wise multiplication of \(\mathbf{u}\) and \(\mathbf{v}\), \begin{equation*} \mathbf{u} \odot \mathbf{v} = \left[ u_0 v_0, ~~ u_1 v_1, ~~ \ldots,~~ u_{n-1} v_{n-1} \right]. \end{equation*}

Given \(n\)-vectors \(\mathbf{u}\) and \(\mathbf{v}\), the dot product or inner product is denoted \(\mathbf{u} \cdot \mathbf{v}\) or \(\mathbf{u}^T \mathbf{v}\) and is the scalar value given by multiplying corresponding components and summing them up: \begin{equation*} \mathbf{u} \cdot \mathbf{v} = \sum_{i=0}^{n-1} u_i v_i. \end{equation*}

For a mathematical object \(\mathbf{u}\) with an inner product operator \(\langle , \rangle\), the norm squared is denoted by \(\| \mathbf{u} \|^2\) and defined as \begin{equation*}   \| \mathbf{u} \|^2 = \langle \mathbf{u}, \mathbf{u} \rangle . \end{equation*}

For a mathematical object \(\mathbf{u}\) with an inner product operator \(\langle ~,~ \rangle\), the norm is denoted by \(\| \mathbf{u} \|\) and defined as \begin{equation*} \left \Vert \mathbf{u} \right \Vert = \sqrt{\langle \mathbf{u}, \mathbf{u} \rangle }. \end{equation*}
A vector \(\mathbf{v}\) is a unit vector if \(\| \mathbf{v} \| =1.\)

The distance between two \(n\)-vectors \(\mathbf{a}\) and \(\mathbf{b}\) is the norm of the difference between the vectors, \begin{equation*} d\left(\mathbf{a}, \mathbf{b}\right) = \left\| \mathbf{a} - \mathbf{b} \right\| = \left\|\mathbf{b} - \mathbf{a} \right\|. \end{equation*}
